channel.title: Parenting, what are your views on it?
channel.description:
Everyone thinks they would be a good parent, so I'm asking you what your views on parenting are and what concepts you will/would adopt when having a child? I am interested to see peoples ideals.
[b]‎"PARENTAL WARNING: Exposing your children to Life may increase the risk of Death by up to 100%"[/b]

item.title: Parenting, what are your views on it?
item.dc:creator: @srt8 srt8
item.description:
@srt8 wrote:

[quote=“Miss Silabsoft, post:41, topic:437136”][quote author=Phillipé link=topic=539851.msg3971780#msg3971780 date=1334233000]

My little sister had a friend who, when she needed to be picked up from school, her mom brought her a snack in the car for her to eat on the way home, and then they ate dinner again, and then she had another snack. Yes she was fat.[/quote]

Um, What’s the problem with this? I ate snacks every single day after school, then dinner, then several more snacks between dinner and bed time. I’ve always been underweight.

Maybe schools should have mandatory physical education daily though. Sometimes teachers are better then some parents.

Nothing wrong with snacks… unless you’re eating fatty american snacks.

They are fattening but I usually just eat sunflower seeds lol

snacks in my house always consisted of some freshly washed veggies or fruit.

Now it’s all rice or noodles.

QFT

on topic: anyone else really scared to have a child I can’t be the only one that thinks that “1 in 88” for autism is really high.[/quote]

It is really scary thinking something might be wrong with your child, but you can’t let it bother you. I drive myself and moparisthebest worrying about our daughter, but I have to remind myself that I can’t do anything about it

Read full topic
item.source: Parenting, what are your views on it?

item.title: Parenting, what are your views on it?
item.dc:creator: @m1lkman m1lkman
item.description:
@m1lkman wrote:

Yz85Racer:

Niall is right though. How many of you, when you did something wrong at a younger age, did your best to lie/cover it up/blame it on someone else because you didn’t want to be smacked? I know I did.

I lied because I felt guilty and didn’t want anyone to know about it but my conscience wouldn’t let me keep lying, so I eventually came clean. Hardly ever lied to my parents back then. Still don’t.

Read full topic
item.source: Parenting, what are your views on it?

item.title: Parenting, what are your views on it?
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

Niall:

[quote author=sanga282 link=topic=539851.msg3974358#msg3974358 date=1334485824]it’s conditioning not to do certain things for fear of punishment it has nothing to do respect.

and in my experience, this makes things worse because when the child inevitably fucks up (they’re a child, their reasoning isn’t exactly sound) they’ll try their best to cover it up to avoid being smacked/beaten, and the fear of being smacked doesn’t necessarily sway children from doing wrong, to use a real world analogy, countries that have the death penalty still have people committing crimes where the punishment is death

non physical/verbal(read: screaming, shouting) punishment isn’t about trying to reason with the child it’s about showing disapproval without the need to instil fear to achieve the same results[/quote]
arguably it still instills fear but just not for the same result

Read full topic
item.source: Parenting, what are your views on it?

item.title: Parenting, what are your views on it?
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

sanga282:

it’s conditioning not to do certain things for fear of punishment it has nothing to do respect.

and in my experience, this makes things worse because when the child inevitably fucks up (they’re a child, their reasoning isn’t exactly sound) they’ll try their best to cover it up to avoid being smacked/beaten, and the fear of being smacked doesn’t necessarily sway children from doing wrong, to use a real world analogy, countries that have the death penalty still have people committing crimes where the punishment is death

non physical/verbal(read: screaming, shouting) punishment isn’t about trying to reason with the child it’s about showing disapproval without the need to instil fear to achieve the same results

Read full topic
item.source: Parenting, what are your views on it?

item.title: Parenting, what are your views on it?
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

I believe children should be smacked when they do wrong and the reason is simple, it’s not about building respect by doing that it’s about teaching a child what is wrong, sure if you want to try and reason with a kid then be my guest, however those few minutes of sudden pain that are associated with doing something wrong are rncoursgements not to do it again, it’s conditioning not to do certain things for fear of punishment it has nothing to do respect. Earning respect with your children comes from interacting with them throughout their life. As Mpman said I was smacked as a child to and it didn’t do me any harm, I feel it made me a more well rounded person tbf

Read full topic
item.source: Parenting, what are your views on it?

item.title: Parenting, what are your views on it?
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Miss Silabsoft:

on topic: anyone else really scared to have a child I can’t be the only one that thinks that “1 in 88” for autism is really high.

I’m not an expert on autism, but I guess some forms of autism are worse than others. Some might result in a completely disfunctional human being, while others will result in someone who is a bit odd, but completely accepted by society.

1 in 88 sounds high, but I wouldn’t worry.

Read full topic

My little sister had a friend who, when she needed to be picked up from school, her mom brought her a snack in the car for her to eat on the way home, and then they ate dinner again, and then she had another snack. Yes she was fat.[/quote]

Um, What’s the problem with this? I ate snacks every single day after school, then dinner, then several more snacks between dinner and bed time. I’ve always been underweight.

Maybe schools should have mandatory physical education daily though. Sometimes teachers are better then some parents.

Nothing wrong with snacks… unless you’re eating fatty american snacks.

They are fattening but I usually just eat sunflower seeds lol

snacks in my house always consisted of some freshly washed veggies or fruit.

item.source: Parenting, what are your views on it?

item.title: Parenting, what are your views on it?
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

[quote=“Nueb35, post:27, topic:437136”][quote author=Greeny link=topic=539851.msg3953424#msg3953424 date=1332513476]
True. However fresh organic ingredients without preservatives and all the added junk is definitely more expensive than processed foods. Not obscenely so, but still more expensive.
[/quote]

I don’t think the preservatives and other junk are that much of a factor. What Americans need is a low calorie, high exercise diet. They eat larger than normal (normal in the US) portions and barely excercise.[/quote]
Some. Id say we have alot of body builders and fitness junkies and anorexics than we do fat people. And the statistic is “overweight” which can as little as 10 pounds. Not everyone here looks obese but a gut is common ish. We don’t really have a middle ground. Youre either really skinny, gut-fat, or fit/toned/built.

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:26, topic:437136”][quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=539851.msg3953432#msg3953432 date=1332514154]

healthy food is cheaper in America I hope you know that

It might be true, but wouldn’t be better to increase the tax on unhealthy food and not fine people?
[/quote]

Both boil down to the same thing. You either fine people who are too fat, hoping they will eat healthy food, or you increase tax on unhealthy food, hoping people will eat healthy food instead. But when is someone fat? What food is healthy? Is all low fat food healthy, or only organically grown food? Lobby groups will have fun changing the definitions of these terms.[/quote]
We don’t tax anything based on what it contains. If you know how to eat it in moderation then you’re fine. Fat isnt all that bad for you, but it can build up fast and become detrimental to your health. Im not overweight and im not underweight, I eat a fuckton of junk but I also love eating salads and actual meals, and I also exercise regularly.

If they start young we wouldn’t have these bullshit shows like “the biggest loser” and crybabies on dr phil.

Of course im excluding thyroid issues

Read full topic

item.source: Parenting, what are your views on it?

item.title: Parenting, what are your views on it?
item.dc:creator: @srt8 srt8
item.description:
@srt8 wrote:

Being a parent for 5 weeks doesn’t make me an expert, but I have noticed little things with our daughter. I swear, she can feel when I’m angry or frustrated and that makes her cry like crazy so I try to stay calm and happy around her. I remember being spanked once by my father, I don’t remember what I did, but I never did anything to be spanked again because I was afraid of him. I don’t want my kids to be afraid that we will hurt them, so I do not believe in spanking. I would hope that raising them as best we can will help them make good choices.

Now, if one of them intentionally did something really bad or hurt someone, I would have to reconsider.

Read full topic
item.source: Parenting, what are your views on it?
